overview: From 2025-10-12 to 2025-10-19, ethereum-optimism/docs had 4 new PRs (2 merged), 2 new issues, and 39 active contributors.

topIssues.title: [2024 Q4 Audit] [page-path]
topIssues.author: kelvin7891
topIssues.body:
<!-- this template is intended for internal OP Labs usage -->

## Description of the updates required

<!-- Write a description of the current state of the page. -->

### Acceptance criteria

<!-- Definition of done for the assignee -->

### Resources

<!-- Supporting docs, points of contact, and any additional helpful info -->

### Action items

<!-- The process for working through this issue for example:
1. Read through resources and meet with SME
2. Write the first draft
3. Share draft with SMEs and implement feedback
4. Peer review
5. Final SME review
6. Publish -->

## Github issue label criteria

> Choose the appropriate github issue labels for each page.

<details>

<summary>Priority</summary>

- `p-on-hold`: (Defer) Tasks that are currently not actionable due to various reasons like waiting for external inputs, dependencies, or resource constraints. These are reviewed periodically to decide if they can be moved to a more active status.
- `p-low`: (Nice to do) Tasks that have minimal impact on core operations and no immediate deadlines. These tasks are often more about quality of life improvements rather than essential needs.
- `p-medium`: (Could do) Tasks that need to be done but are less critical than high-priority tasks. These often improve processes or efficiency but can be postponed if necessary without immediate severe repercussions.
- `p-high`: (Should do) Important tasks that contribute significantly to long-term goals but may not have an immediate deadline. Delaying these tasks could have considerable negative effects but are not as immediate as critical tasks.
- `p-critical`: Tasks that have immediate deadlines or significant consequences if not completed on time. These are non-negotiable and often linked to core business functions or legal requirements. 
</details>

<details>

<summary>T-shirt size</summary>

- `s-XS`: (< 1 day) Very simple tasks that require minimal time and effort.
- `s-S`: (few days) Tasks that are straightforward but require a bit more time to complete.
- `s-M`: (1-2 weeks) Tasks that involve a moderate level of complexity and collaboration.
- `s-L`: (several weeks) Complex tasks that require significant time investment and coordination across multiple teams. 
- `s-XL`: (> 1 month) Very large and complex projects that involve extensive planning, execution, and testing. 
</details>

<details>

<summary>Content evaluation</summary>
- `a-delete`: don't need this page 
- `a-duplicate`: some content lives elsewhere 
- `a-minor`: needs small revisions 
- `a-moderate`: needs moderate revisions 
- `a-critical`: needs a lot of work
</details>

## MDX Metadata format

> We will be adding better metadata to the header of each page. 
> If I was actively searching for this page on google and this description was the search result, would I know it's the correct page?
> Parse the component and feature tags to add.

```mdx
---
title: "Your Title Here"
tags: ["tag1", "tag2"]
description: "A short description of the content."
---
```

<details>
<summary>Component tags</summary>

```
op-node
op-geth
op-reth
op-erigon
op-nethermind
batcher
standard-bridge
sequencer
l1-contracts
l2-contracts
precompiles
predeploys
preinstalls
op-proposer
op-challenger
op-gov-token
op-supervisor
op-conductor
fp-contracts
cannon
op-program
asterisk
kona
superchain-registry
supersim
dev-console
opsm
mcp
mcp-l2
deputy-guardian
liveness-guard
dispute-mon
op-beat
op-signer
monitorism
blockspace-charters
op-workbench
kubernetes-infrastructure
devops-tooling
artifacts-packaging
sequencer-in-a-box
devnets
performance-tooling
peer-management-service
proxyd
zdd-service
snapman
security-tools
superchain-ops
op-deployer
```
</details>

<details>
<summary>Engineering tags</summary>

```
eng-platforms
eng-growth
eng-devx
eng-protocol
eng-proofs
eng-evm
eng-security
```
</details>

topContributors.summary: geoknee: This week, geoknee focused on the Jovian upgrade, implementing a key operator fee fix in `op-geth#696` (+77/-32 lines). They supported this effort by contributing to the design documentation, adding a new failure mode analysis in `design-docs#347`, and creating several issues to track further testing and edge cases. Through their 11 code reviews and contributions, geoknee's work primarily involved bug fixes, documentation, and testing.

maurelian: This week, maurelian focused on refactoring and feature development, merging a PR to make test initialization contracts abstract in ethereum-optimism/optimism#17889. They also advanced work on Safe security and usability by opening three PRs to enforce owner-only actions and improve styling (#17903, #17900, #17883). In addition to their own coding efforts, which primarily touched test files, maurelian was highly active in code review, providing 18 reviews across the repository.

bitwiseguy: Focused on improving the `op-deployer` in the `ethereum-optimism/optimism` repository, merging three pull requests to enhance its reliability and test coverage. Their most significant contribution was adding extensive CLI tests in PR #17849 (+1381/-120 lines), complemented by a fix to the upgrader (#17848) and the re-enabling of a V3 upgrade test (#17852). Alongside this work, they provided 11 code reviews, with their overall efforts concentrated on tests and bug fixes.

sebastianst: Focused on the Jovian release, updating the Data Availability footprint limit specifications to use `blobGasUsed` (specs#800) and merging a related fix for OP Legacy header verification in `op-geth#697`. In addition to opening a PR to implement these spec changes (`optimism#17861`), he was highly collaborative, providing 17 code reviews this week. His work was split between bug fixes and other feature development, touching both core code and tests.

scharissis: Focused on improving the reliability of acceptance tests in the `ethereum-optimism/optimism` repository, merging seven pull requests to address test flakiness. Key contributions included a feature to move notifications to Slack (PR #17843) and a significant fix for flaky tests that removed 63 lines of code (PR #17891). This work, supplemented by five code reviews, was primarily concentrated on tests and configuration files to enhance overall test stability.

AmadiMichael: Focused on a significant refactoring effort targeting bug fixes, resulting in the open pull request `ethereum-optimism/optimism#17902` with substantial code changes (+7983/-8838 lines). Alongside this work, they were highly collaborative, conducting 16 code reviews which included 3 approvals. The code modifications show a primary focus on test and configuration files.

pcw109550: Focused on enhancing the acceptance tests for `ethereum-optimism/optimism`, merging two pull requests to improve test suite robustness. They made a significant contribution by adding extensive new tests for reorg and gap-filling scenarios in PR #17893 (+521 lines), and also improved test stability by adding retry logic in PR #17894. This work reflects a primary focus on tests and other related code changes.

ajsutton: Focused on improving the dispute monitor's reliability, merging a fix to correctly handle invalid nodes that have not processed certain blocks (optimism#17831). They were also highly engaged in collaboration, providing 15 code reviews, and proactively identified further improvements by opening several related issues (#17814, #17886). Their code contributions were primarily centered on bug fixes and enhancing test coverage.

Inphi: Focused on improving development tooling and test coverage within Optimism, merging an integration test for the `op-deployer` (ethereum-optimism/optimism#17865). They also began work to update the upgrade method for `disputegame-v2` (ethereum-optimism/optimism#17874) and were highly collaborative, providing 11 code reviews. Their contributions show a primary focus on bug fixes and testing, modifying code, test, and configuration files.

axelKingsley: Focused on preparing components for release and new feature development in the `ethereum-optimism/optimism` repository, notably merging a PR to set the v0.1.0 version and Docker target for `op-supernode` (#17906). They also began work on `op-conductor`'s Flashblocks integration (PR #17880), provided feedback across 9 reviews, and pushed 36 commits with significant code changes (+8831/-1632 lines). This activity shows a primary focus on general development, tests, and bug fixes.

smartcontracts: This week, they focused on operational enhancements and testing efficiency for the Superchain, merging three pull requests across the `ethereum-optimism/superchain-ops` and `ethereum-optimism/optimism` repositories. Key contributions included adding validation instructions for op-txverify (superchain-ops#1251) and reducing fuzz runs to improve testing (optimism#17877). They also actively supported the team by reviewing 9 pull requests.

devin-ai-integration: Focused on improving test quality in the `ethereum-optimism/optimism` repository, merging two refactoring pull requests to improve test organization and coverage (#17839, #17896). They were also active in discussions with 14 PR comments and have five additional open PRs aimed at further enhancing test coverage. This activity indicates a clear focus on improving the testing infrastructure for the Optimism project.
mds1: Focused on team enablement this week through extensive code review. They provided feedback on 20 pull requests, including 8 approvals, helping to advance the team's work.

Wazabie: This week, Wazabie opened a pull request in the `ethereum-optimism/superchain-ops` repository (#1252) to update `SetRespectedGameTypeTemplate.sol`. The work involved a small modification (+11/-8 lines) focused entirely on test files.

yashvardhan-kukreja: Focused on coordinating infrastructure upgrades and investigating system issues within the ethereum-optimism/optimism repository. They drove the "Fusaka readiness for Flashblocks components" (#17853) and the deployment of "rollup-boost partial healthiness tolerance" (#17680) by creating and managing a series of tracking issues. Additionally, they supported the team by providing feedback across 9 code reviews and investigating new timeout issues (#17835, #17858).

nonsense: This week, nonsense focused on new development, authoring a notable amount of code (+524/-58 lines across 34 files). They also supported the team by providing 3 code reviews. Their code changes indicate a focus on other work and tests.

aliersh focused on improving the AI contracts testing infrastructure within the `ethereum-optimism/optimism` repository. Their most impactful contribution was PR #17876, which added Slack notifications and included several bug fixes (+141/-45 lines), complemented by another fix for artifact exclusion failures in PR #17840. This work reflects a primary focus on bug fixes and enhancing the reliability of the test suite.

bradleycamacho: Focused on a large-scale documentation refactor within the `ethereum-optimism/docs` repository. This effort is captured in two open pull requests, #1791 and #1792, which propose a significant information architecture restructure across 263 files (+7193/-7877 lines).
Vaios0x: Focused on the ethereum-optimism/optimism repository, opening two pull requests (#17845, #17844) for review.

opgitgovernance: Focused on improving test stability, merging a significant refactor in `ethereum-optimism/optimism#17851` (+2520/-4145 lines) to address flakiness in the acceptance tests. They continued this effort with two additional open PRs and also handled administrative metrics reporting by creating and closing two issues. This week's contributions were entirely focused on tests.

joshklop: Focused on improving client and testing infrastructure in `ethereum-optimism/optimism`, pushing a substantial volume of code changes (+3398/-896 lines). They opened two PRs to improve beacon client robustness (#17866) and align mock behavior (#17881), and also merged a small dynamic assignment fix for the devstack (#17904). This work was primarily focused on general development, with additional efforts in tests and bug fixes.

MSilb7: This week, MSilb7 focused on the `op-analytics` repository, making key updates to financial data. They merged a substantial modification to revenue wallets in PR ethereum-optimism/op-analytics#1754, which included over 800 lines of additions. Additionally, they shipped a fix for collective balances in PR #1755, with their overall efforts split between bug fixes and other configuration-related work.

mbaxter: Focused on supporting the team's progress this week, providing extensive feedback across 9 pull request reviews. They also helped define upcoming work in the `ethereum-optimism/optimism` repository by creating an issue (#17257) to track the implementation of the v2 dispute game.

JosepBove: Focused on new feature development, opening a pull request to add IERC165 support on SaferSafes (ethereum-optimism/optimism#17864). In addition to this work, which involved changes across 21 files, they also supported the team by providing 3 code reviews. Their contributions this week were concentrated on modifications to tests and configuration files.
almanax-ai: Actively participated in code reviews this week, providing feedback via comments on 8 different pull requests.

janjakubnanista: Focused on operational health and CI improvements, merging a pull request to enhance CI error messages in `superchain-registry` (#1118). As part of on-call duties, they opened issues to address a CI failure (#17754) and enable log retention (#17859), while also reviewing three other pull requests. Their code contributions this week were primarily a mix of bug fixes and other operational work.

jelias2: This week, jelias2 focused on infrastructure maintenance, merging a fix for a typo in `conductor-ops` within the `ethereum-optimism/infra` repository (PR #492). They also supported the team by reviewing and approving three pull requests and actively participating in discussions on one issue and one pull request.
BrycePy: This week, BrycePy opened a pull request to update a dependency in the `ethereum-optimism/op-geth` repository (op-geth#695).

RyanSquared: Focused on infrastructure development within the Optimism project, opening a work-in-progress pull request to add a containerized environment for hash-locked Mise flows (ethereum-optimism/optimism#17863).

CreeptoGengar: This week, CreeptoGengar focused on enhancing op-conductor, opening a pull request (ethereum-optimism/optimism#17837) to add a `replica_id` label for multi-replica monitoring. This feature work comprised 7 commits and modifications to 7 files (+198/-28 lines), touching both new code and the corresponding tests.
wiz-inc-a178a98b5d: Focused on collaboration this week by providing feedback on pull requests. They contributed through 5 reviews and 6 PR comments.

pauldowman: Focused on testing and maintenance within the ethereum-optimism/optimism repository this week. They created an issue to add new acceptance tests (#17774) and merged a minor PR to update a TODO item (#17885). Their code contributions were concentrated entirely within test files.
tremarkley: Focused on supporting the team through code review this week. They helped move work forward by providing 5 approvals and 1 comment on pull requests.

theochap: Focused on improving test reliability this week by addressing a bug in the `ethereum-optimism/optimism` repository. They merged a fix for the acceptance tests for op-reth (PR #17882). This contribution was entirely focused on bugfix work within the codebase.
0xwitty: Focused on documentation maintenance this week, merging a pull request to fix a broken link in the design docs (ethereum-optimism/design-docs#346).

opmxwell: This week, opmxwell focused on repository maintenance, merging a pull request in ethereum-optimism/community-hub (#1195). This contribution updated a single configuration file with a minor change.

mdqst: Focused on documentation and bug fixes this week, opening three pull requests across different repositories. They addressed documentation issues by fixing broken links in `design-docs` (#345) and `superchain-ops` (#1249), and also submitted a bugfix for DataFrame mapping in `op-analytics` (#1753). This activity shows a focus on documentation and bug fixes.
tynes: Focused on bugfix work this week, committing a fix with 189 lines of new code, and supported the team by reviewing and approving 2 pull requests.
ericbrown99: Supported the team this week by reviewing and approving 3 pull requests.
alcueca: Focused on supporting the team through code review this week, providing 3 reviews and approving 2 pull requests. They also pushed 3 commits related to bugfix and other work across 3 files.

guidiaz: This week, guidiaz focused on address settlement for Ethereum and Base, opening a pull request in ethereum-optimism/ethereum-optimism.github.io (#1224). This work involved modifications to two configuration files and also included one review comment on another PR.

moara-ops: This week's activity centered on a contribution to the `ethereum-optimism/ethereum-optimism.github.io` repository, where they opened a pull request (#1223) to add ENSC to lisk. The proposed changes, which included one PR comment, primarily involved modifications to configuration files.

njokuScript: This week, njokuScript's efforts were directed towards expanding the Base ecosystem by opening a pull request to add the DRIP token (ethereum-optimism/ethereum-optimism.github.io#1221). This contribution consisted of a single commit adding 668 lines of code across two files. The changes indicate a focus on configuration work.
